message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Peritonitis is inflammation of the peritoneum, which covers the inner wall of the abdomen and the organs. In this case, the patient's severe abdominal pain and history of peptic ulcer suggest peritonitis. Forced cough elicits abdominal pain is the non-invasive maneuver that would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis of peritonitis in this patient. It is known as the Markle sign and indicates peritoneal irritation. Pain aroused with gentle intensity/pressure at the costovertebral angle suggests kidney inflammation or infection. Rectal examination showing guaiac positive stool suggests gastrointestinal bleeding. Absent bowel sounds on auscultation suggest intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Peritonitis is typically associated with guarding, rebound tenderness, and pain worsening with coughing or movement. Therefore, forced cough eliciting abdominal pain would be the most helpful non-invasive maneuver to confirm the diagnosis of peritonitis in this patient. None of the other options are specific for peritonitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient will not allow abdominal palpation, we need to look for a non-invasive maneuver that can help confirm the diagnosis of peritonitis. Option A is the most likely to be helpful as a forced cough can cause pain in the abdomen in the presence of peritonitis. Option B suggests renal involvement, Option C suggests GI bleeding, and Option D suggests intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Forced cough elicits abdominal pain suggests peritoneal inflammation, which confirms the diagnosis of peritonitis. The other options may be indicative of other conditions. Pain at the costovertebral angle can suggest renal inflammation, guaiac positive stool can suggest gastrointestinal bleeding, and absent bowel sounds can suggest ileus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most helpful non-invasive maneuver in confirming the diagnosis of peritonitis in this patient is forced cough eliciting abdominal pain. This is known as the cough test, which is a simple and reliable method for assessing peritoneal irritation. The other options are not specific to peritonitis and may be present in other conditions as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Peritonitis is inflammation of the lining of the abdominal cavity and causes intense abdominal pain. Forced cough elicits abdominal pain because it increases intra-abdominal pressure, which exacerbates the inflammation. The other options (B-D) are not specific enough to confirm the diagnosis of peritonitis.

Option B helps diagnose renal involvement, option C helps diagnose gastrointestinal bleeding, and option D helps diagnose bowel obstruction but does not confirm peritonitis.

Option B is not helpful in confirming the diagnosis of peritonitis, as it is more indicative of kidney inflammation or infection. Option C suggests gastrointestinal bleeding, but may not be specific to peritonitis. Option D is an indication of bowel obstruction, but also not specific to peritonitis.

Option A, forced cough eliciting abdominal pain, is a classic sign of peritonitis, indicating irritation of the peritoneum. Options B, C, and D may be present in peritonitis but are not specific to the condition and may also be present in other conditions.
